article: I drove a school bus as a part-time job. Thirty-nine children all had stories to tell me about their summers. Charlie though _ me. From the first day on Charlie was _ . If a fight broke out I didn't have to turn my _ to know who had started it. If a girl was crying chances were that Charlie had _ her hair. No matter how I spoke to him gently or _ he wouldn't say a word. He'd just stare at me with those big gray eyes of his. One day I found a small tin heart on the bus was gone. "Does anyone know _ happened to the little heart here" I asked. Some children cried "Charlie _ it Search him" When I asked him to come forward his gaze burned into my eyes. I stuck my hand into one of his pockets. Then I felt it--the _ outline of the small tin heart. Charlie stared at me for a long time. There were no _ in those big gray eyes no plea for mercy. He seemed to be waiting for what he'd come to _ from the world. I was about to pull the tin heart out of Charlie's pocket _ I stopped myself. Let him keep it, I said "It must have fallen off before I got here." Without a word Charlie _ to his seat. When he got off at his stop, he didn't so much as glance at me. Several days later just that _ Charlie moved away... A dozen years after retirement we met in the street. To my _ , he hugged me. After he let go, he pulled something from his pocket and held it up for me to see. An old key chain... bent out of _ , the lettering faded . You _ probably guess what it was--the little tin heart. "You were the only one who kept trying." He explained. We _ again and went our separate ways. I am so _ I'd done a good job.
